awd_titl_txt: SCH: EXP: RadiOptiMeter: Long-Term and Fine-Grained Breathing Volume Monitoring for Sleep Disordered Breathing (SDB)
awd_abstract_narration:
Sleep disordered breathing (SDB) in children is considered to be a public health problem with serious consequences such as decreased cognitive function, poor school performance, daytime sleepiness and increased cardiovascular risk. Current diagnosis of SDB is performed in hospital sleep laboratories by monitoring patients with a host of cardiorespiratory sensors attached at various positions on the patient?s body. This obtrusive form of monitoring is inconvenient to patients and require tremendous amount of attention from technicians to ensure study quality. Children, especially, tolerate the study very poorly; often removing sensors, having trouble sleeping, and necessitating repeat investigations. This project aims to develop a new method to remotely and continuously monitor breathing volume and breathing patterns of human subjects during sleep studies using optical signals assisted by radio frequency signals. We introduce RadiOptiMeter, a hybrid radio-optical breath volume monitoring approach that couple the unique characteristics of radio frequency (RF) signals with image stream captured by a depth-CO2-thermal camera to accurately estimate breathing volume of sleeping patients from afar. This study is the first step in the development of non-invasive respiratory monitoring. Utilizing this novel and non-invasive device to measure breathing during sleep will begin a research program to promote future diagnosis of SDB in the comfort of the child?s home, with no in-hospital laboratory expenses or the expense of the disposable medical equipment which equates to thousands of dollars a year in each sleep laboratory.
 
This project will investigate a new method to continuously monitor breathing volume and breathing patterns of humans during in-hospital sleep studies using radio frequency and optical signals. We introduce RadiOptiMeter, a hybrid radio-optical breath volume monitoring approach that couple the unique characteristics of radio frequency (RF) signals with image stream captured by a depth-CO2-thermal camera to accurately and continuously estimate breathing volume of sleeping patients from afar. We propose techniques to address challenges brought about by the body movement during sleep, environmental wireless signal noises, and the diversity of patient populations. An expected outcome is a robust and accurate breathing volume monitoring system for SDB studies. The cooperation between each of the proposed devices allows us to exploit the synergistic effects of the devices to cover the limitations imposed by each device type and provides system redundancies. These redundancies ensure reliability for long-term monitoring tasks, which are critical for clinical applications. Our proposed research will make the following key contributions to enable new non-contact vital signal monitoring system: (1) Analytical models, experimental tools, and evaluation results of a breathing volume estimation method using a vision-based system (VVE) which include 4D volumetric model and skeletal structure analysis from depth- CO2-thermal (DCT) camera outputs. (2) Analytical models, experimental hardware and software components, and evaluation results of a RF-based breathing volume estimation (RVE) system, that uses neural-network-based machine learning for chest displacement- to-volume matching. (3) A hybrid radio-optical breathing volume estimation system (RadiOptiMeter) that synergistically combines the VVE and RVE to perform continuous and fine-grain monitoring. RadiOptiMeter includes body movement tracking, automatic antenna steering, and a set of controlling and synchronizing algorithms for a harmonic integration of the whole system. This collaborative effort between researchers at the Department of Computer Science and Engineering and medical doctors at Sleep Medicine Research at the Children?s Hospital Colorado is the first step in the development of non-invasive respiratory monitoring. A novel non-invasive device to measure breathing during sleep will be the first step in the necessary foundational research to promote future diagnosis of SDB in the comfort of the child?s home, with no in-hospital laboratory expenses or the expense of the disposable medical equipment which equates to thousands of dollars a year in each sleep laboratory. This project also provides an excellent methodd to train graduate students to conduct this vision-based research project. The RadiOptiMeter concepts serves as an exciting and appealing tool for structuring a variety of educational activities. Moreover, the project results will be disseminated through scholarly publications and active outreach through our existing and potential industrial partners.

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this project was to study and design a camera-RF system to monitor human breathing-volume during sleep. This project pursued the vision of a system that couples the unique characteristics of radio frequency (RF) signals with image streams captured by a depth, CO2-thermal camera to accurately and continuously estimate the breathing volume of sleeping subjects from afar.

We first introduced a novel way to estimate breathing volume using a hybrid radio-camera system. While the RF component estimates breathing volume by observing the effect of chest movements on the phase of the reflected signal, the thermal-depth camera components detect human posture to navigate and guide the RF system to beam to the correct direction and orientation to track the human chest in real-time. The system has the ability to work with the presence of random body movement. In particular, it autonomously tracks the large-scale movements of the patient by observing the skeletal posture obtained by a depth-based camera sensor and moves the radar to a proper location in order to maintain an orthogonal view of the patient’s chest.

To ensure that the RF antenna is always beaming to the correct location on the human chest, we proposed the following two solutions. The first solution is to build a mechanical controller with 360o freedom. While this solution is reliable, it generates much unexpected acoustic noise that affects the user’s sleep behaviors. Thus, a complete acoustically silent RF system with MIMO sensing solution was considered. In particular, we designed a bed dome attached to 32 controllable antennas to remove the need for mechanical scanning procedure. These antennas are placed around the bed dome steering to different areas on the human chest and abdominal. They are uniformly distributed on a dome’s surface that has a haft-cylinder shape with a high of 21 inches and a radius of 17 inches. The system controls each antenna to decide which one acts as a transmitter which one acts as a receiver.

We explored three different solutions to estimate human posture during sleep so that the system can accurately navigate the RF beam to keep track of the human chest. First, we introduced a new method to estimate the skeletal posture in occluded scenario using both depth and thermal imaging through volumetric modeling. We developed a volumetric representation of patient’s thermal distribution within an occluded region, and introduced a coarse-grained skeletal posture estimation technique for identifying joint positions of visually obscured patients. Second, we explored Radar Polarimetry approach to differentiate different materials based on the characteristics of the received signals to estimate the posture. Third, we found that a pressure-sensitive surface is a more suitable and practical solution to estimate the human posture during sleep. However, existing systems have been designed with a very low resolution (32 x 32 sensors). To increase the resolution and size of a large sensing surface such as a sleeping mat, existing techniques required a large amount of electronic circuit (signals multiplexer and microcontrollers) to capture a larger number of sensors (e.g., 1 million sensors). From our study, we could design a sensing surface that includes 1666 x 833 = 1387778 sensors for a similar bed size and only requires 10 input and 10 output pins and one microcontroller.

Last but not least, we designed algorithm taking input from the sensors (RF, thermal, depth, pressure) to detect central sleep apnea and obstructive sleep apnea. Central sleep apnea is a disorder in which the breathing repeatedly stops and starts during sleep. The obstructive sleep apnea happens when the person can’t breathe normally because the upper airway obstruction. The first research direction is to design an algorithms to detect obstructive sleep apnea using only RF signals. The second research direction is to understand the physiological activities of central sleep apnea and design new solution to detect the brain and breathing behaviors of a user thereby detecting central sleep apnea. 

Overall, the project experiments and data analysis were conducted by students and provided them with important research mentoring and experience. The project has enabled graduate students to collaborate with each other and to gain experience with the challenges of building touch communication systems on mobile and wearable devices. 

The research projects have led to multiple publications in top conferences and journals. This project was introduced at multiple undergraduate courses at University of Colorado including CSCI 3511 (Hardware-Software Interface), CSCI 4827 (Embedded System Programming), CSCI 4211 (Mobile Computing and Programming), and CSCI 4739 (Senior Design Project).

The projects involve both end-to-end system implementation and comprehensive theoretical analysis, and thus provided solid professional training to the participating PhD and MS students. The proposed techniques ultimately made an impact on creating a new convenient/seamless/highly secured authentication protocol. It also has an impact of extending to the novel applications to human sensing and human-computer interaction.
